--- title: "RStudio Instructor Training and Certification" subtitle: "This post describes how was for me to do the RStudio Instructor Training and Certification." author: "Beatriz Milz" date: "2022-06-08" bibliography: packages.bib categories: [Teaching, RStudio, Communities, Translation] image: "featured-photo.jpeg" toc: true draft: false --- ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: \[TO DO: WRITE AN INTRODUCTION\] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Introduction In 2020, I did the [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/) Instructor Training and Certification. This post aims to describe how as it, in order to possibly offer information and help other people interested to undertake this training. [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/) offers the possibility to do the instructor certification on the packages [tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org/) and [shiny](https://shiny.rstudio.com/). All the necessary information is available [on this site](https://education.rstudio.com/trainers/), but I will add some extra links here as well! > Important: I did the entire training process with [Greg Wilson](https://twitter.com/gvwilson), however he is no longer involved with it. > So I don't know if any of the steps have changed. > Here I will describe what the process was when I did the training. ## The importance of the R community First of all: I would like to point out that the R community was essential for me to be able to take this training. When I found out about the existence of this certification, I soon came across a difficulty to participate: on the website it said that it was necessary to pay (in dollars) to do the training. For those who are Brazilians, we know how the local currency is very devalued, and this ends up making it difficult for many Brazilian people to participate. So I let it go, until I saw a [post](https://yabellini.netlify.app/blog/2020_rstudiocertification_es/) on [Yanina Saibene](https://twitter.com/yabellini)'s blog talking about the training and certification that she took. I got in touch with her (who I had met in person at [LatinR 2019](https://latin-r.com/)) to find out more about what the training was like for her. She put me in touch with a group of people who are part of [several chapters of R-Ladies](https://rladies.org/) in Latin America, who were starting to organize a study group (and support!) to do the training. In addition, she also gave me more information on how to make this financially possible. For this study group, we created a Slack channel, where we shared tips, exercise resolutions and questions. In addition, we had weekly Zoom meetings to discuss chapters from the book [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/) (also available in Spanish [this link](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/)). The guidance from [Yanina Saibene](https://twitter.com/yabellini) and the support from the study group were essential for me to prepare for the exams, and to feel confident in taking them. ## How to start the training process? If you are interested in carrying out the training process, the first step to get started is to read the instructions that are available [on this page](https://education.rstudio.com/trainers/). > When filling out the form, carefully answer the two optional questions at the end of the form: > > - The first is about being part of underrepresented groups in data science; in this case, describe well which groups you are a part of, and point out your contributions to the R community. > > - The second is about the reduction of the application fee (*fee waiver*) for people from developing countries (*lower-income countries*). ## Training After receiving a message of acceptance, it was necessary to indicate one of the possible dates to carry out the training. The training I did was carried out online in two mornings, using Zoom tool. The focus of the training was not about programming in R, but on teaching! All the contents of the slides used are available [at this link](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/13ohFt3D0EJ5PDbMaWTxnHH-hwA7G0IvY). Much of the content presented was similar to the training offered by [The Carpentries](https://carpentries.org/) (which I described [in this post](https://beatrizmilz.com/posts/2020-02-22- the-carpentries-how-to-do-instructor-training/)), and also with the content of the book written by [Greg Wilson](https://twitter.com/gvwilson), entitled [Teach Tech Together](https://teachtogether.tech/). ## Certification exam After completing the training, the next step was to take the teaching and certification exam (in my case, was about tidyverse). [In this link](https://education.rstudio.com/blog/2020/02/instructor-certification-exams/) it is possible to access an example of exams, made available by [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/) for study. There was no correct order to take the tests! Another important point is that the tests were done with the screen shared, and we could do a Google search about the topics. But the exam had a time limit, so it's important to pay attention to the time you spend searching! ### Teaching exam The teaching exam consisted of a 15-minute demonstration class, and aswering some questions about teaching. Before the test itself, it was necessary to send the materials to be used in a demonstration class. The materials I prepared are available on this page: (and the code is also available in this [GitHub repository](https://github.com/beatrizmilz/RStudio_Certification) . I created a page for the material using the package [distill](https://rstudio.github.io/distill/) [@R-distill], the presentation made with the package [xaringan](https ://slides.yihui.org/xaringan/) [@R-xaringan], two exercises to do at the end of the class using the package [learnr](https://rstudio.github.io/learnr/) [@ R-learnr], the live code demo was performed using the IDE [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/), and a concept map created with the tool [CMap Tools](https://cmap.ihmc .us/). But these are the tools that *I* chose to use, and I recommend that you use whichever is most comfortable for you! The only mandatory tool to be used in this step is the IDE [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/) (which is easy to understand why...). ### tidyverse exam The tidyverse exam consisted of solving several exercises using R and tidyverse. The recommendation of [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/) to study for this test is to read the book [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/). I don't have much to say about this step, just practice and use it as much as possible in your daily life and work, so you'll have more experience and be able to solve problems faster during the test. ## Approval! After passing the exams, I received an email with a certificate, and they asked me some information to be added to the list of certified trainers. The page containing my information can be accessed through [this link](https://education.rstudio.com/trainers/people/milz+beatriz/), and the certificate received was this: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Certificate received after completing the'Tidyverse Instructor Certification'.](https://beatrizmilz.com/img/certificado-rstudio.jpg){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: In addition, I was also invited to participate in an RStudio Slack channel, where other people that did the training talk about topics related to the training, such as teaching, didactics, R, tidyverse, shiny, among others. And I couldn't miss the celebration either, right? Due to the pandemic, the meeting with friends was online. There was also a thank you tweet:

Muito feliz em dizer que sou uma instrutora de #tidyverse certificada pela RStudio! ðŸŽ‰

I'm so happy to tell that I'm a certified tidyverse Instructor!

Thanks @gvwilson and @RStudioEDU for this great oportunity. https://t.co/NL4SeT4mxN

— Beatriz Milz (@BeaMilz) October 2, 2020
## It's the English? In my opinion, it is important to have some experience with English, because the training is live and in English. I don't know if RStudio has plans to provide training in other languages (like [The Carpentries](https://carpentries.org/), where there are already some training offerings in Spanish). The exams that I did were applied by [Greg Wilson](https://twitter.com/gvwilson) and accompanied by [Daniel Falbel](https://twitter.com/dfalbel) (who is Brazilian, works at RStudio in the development of the [Torch for R](https://torch.mlverse.org/), and is also one of the founding partners of [Curso-R](https://curso-r.com/)). Daniel's participation made it possible for me to present the teaching demo entirely in Portuguese, in addition to being able to answer the test questions in Portuguese as well. I want to record here my thanks to Greg Wilson for presenting this possibility, and also to Daniel Falbel for agreeing to being part of this process! It was very important for me to feel more relaxed during the test, as I would have to worry less about the language and more about the content of the tests itself. ## Conclusion For me, doing this process was a rich experience where I learned and reflected on important content so that I can share more and more quality content about R. That said, I strongly wish that more people from the Latin American community can go through the training process. ## Acknowledgements ðŸ’œ I already made several acknowledgments throughout the text, but I want to highlight my gratitude to people who were fundamental to this process: - Team at [RStudio](https://rstudio.com/), [Greg Wilson](https://twitter.com/gvwilson) and [Daniel Falbel](https://twitter.com/dfalbel): thank you for making this training possible! - [Yanina Saibene](https://twitter.com/yabellini), for showing me the paths to follow! - It wasn't easy to keep the motivation of studies during the pandemic, but studying in a group helped a lot to continue. It's really cool to practice offering the test class and try to do some reflection and self-feedback, using these points as a starting point! - Articles suggested by [Greg Wilson](https://twitter.com/gvwilson): - [Ten quick tips for creating an effective lesson](https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006915) - [Ten quick tips for delivering programming lessons](https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1007433) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} :::
